thread.title: Jakarta Tightens Security Ahead of President's Cup Final
thread.title_full: Jakarta Tightens Security Ahead of President's Cup Final

title: Jakarta Tightens Security Ahead of President's Cup Final
text:
INDEX Jakarta Tightens Security Ahead of President's Cup Final i All of Jakarta is bracing for the onslaught of football supporters driving from Bandung to cheer on their football club Persib in the President's Cup final against South Sumatra's Sriwijaya FC. Both teams are bitter rivals of Jakarta's own Persija FC, sparking fears of violence between supporters. (JG Photo/ Safir Makki) By : Jakarta Globe | on 3:56 PM October 18, 2015 Category : News , Sports , Football , Featured 
Jakarta. Police have increased security in and around the capital ahead of the President's Cup final on Sunday between South Sumatra's Sriwijaya FC and West Java's Persib Bandung, the bitter rival of Jakarta's own Persija FC. 
Police have deployed 9,000 officers to safeguards the tens of thousands of Persib fans traveling to the capital after local media reported that people believed to be fans of the Jakarta football club were targeting vehicles with Bandung license plates on the eve of the match. 
Detik.com reported that a Jeep with a Bandung license plate was pelted with rocks and brought in for safekeeping at the Jakarta Police headquarters. 
On Sunday, buses carrying Persib supporters received a full police escort. Police even placed some officers inside the bus. 
"We will ensure that [Persib] supporters make it safely to Jakarta and back to Bandung," Jakarta police chief Insp. Gen. Tito Karnavian said. 
Police in Bekasi, on the eastern outskirts of the capital, have deployed 1,500 officers after reports that several Persija fans were waiting on the side of the Cikampek toll road, which links the two cities, on the lookout for Bandung-based vehicle. 
On Sunday, Bekasi police patrolled the toll road and found on Molotov fuel bomb and a plastic bag containing half a kilogram of nails near the East Bekasi toll entrance, Bekasi police chief Sr. Comr. Daniel Bolly Tifaona told Detik.com. 
Police also found four more fuel bombs inside a housing area in Jatiwaringin, Bekasi, the owner of which are unknown. 
In the capital, much of the security is centered near the Gelora Bung Karno stadium, the venue of the match in South Jakarta. The three TransJakarta bus stops around the area as well as the adjoining footbridges are also heavily guarded. 
Police in Bandung also tightened their security, frisking all Persib supporters before they board the hundreds of buses bound for the capital to look for sharp weapons, firecrackers and glass bottles. 
Reuters
